ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Upper Level Japanese and also how to talk about very serious issues from the death penalty all the way to the Genocide in Palestine.
I learned more grammar structures and vocabulary. I also develop better communication skills in Japanese.
Learned about various aspects of Japanese society and culture and how to discuss many thought provoking/difficult topics in Japanese.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: There are no "weaknesses", as even when the workload felt high, Nishimura Sensei was immediately willing to take our worries into account. Truly everything she introduced us to was a strength. We can maybe say some student's Japanese was at times not up to par, and so it was almost impossible to understand what they were saying, but this is not a fault of the course and is common in many higher level language courses.

The weaknesses of this courses was the massive workloads at times. Nishimura Sensei is very good with communication, so if the problem was communicated properly she will try her best to fix it. The is the best strength a course and professor can have.

Strengths: structure/style of the course; course content/material; assignments and quizzes.
Weaknesses: none.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: YES! Higher Level Japanese is like a fun little seminar where we just talk for a while about topics we either read or watched a video on. At the times the readings can be a little difficult, but they are super important to facilitate student learning.
I would recommend this course if you are looking to increase your knowledge of Japanese and get better at conversing in the language.
Yes, but only if you are serious about studying Japanese and can self study and review often.
